annotation.TEXT: This room focuses on Health and Magic upgrades (as noted here). The Goatician will sell you a set number of Meal Cards you can give the Gastronomer to increase your maximum health (with each one increasing in price as you buy more). The Magicist on the right will increase your MP, but you need to get a Relic first before she can do so.

This is the Bard mentioned from before. If you return the music sheets to him, he'll pay you 500 gold for each one you bring him. Bring back all of the music sheets, and you'll get the "Music Lover" achievement.

The Troupple King can give you one of three Ichors for your chalice, making it a one-time use item until you see him again to refill it. The only one worth getting at this point is the Ichor of Renewal, which will restore your health and magic to full (essentially making it the equivalent to a free M-Tank).
Before I move on to any of the main stages, there's one last helpful "upgrade" that can be obtained (though only if you bought a chalice from the Acolyte from before).

Trust me: Despite how strange that sounded, you'll want to buy at least one of these chalices (and eventually both at some point). You'll also want to talk to the guy on the right (Chester), who sells you Relics - basically this game's equivalent to sub-weapons from Castlevania, which can all be stored in and switched-out from your inventory.

There are several breakable passages like these in this game. Most of them are indicated by slight differences in the walls (and sometimes leading to secret areas), but there are a few that are much less subtle in appearance. If you plan on playing this, don't be afraid to go around smacking any suspicious looking walls.

Music Sheets are one of this game's unique collectables. They're found in almost every stage of the game, and can be traded back to a local Bard for a bit of gold. In turn, this unlocks a song (usually the one for the level you found it in) for him to play in the equivalent of a jukebox mode. There's generally two Music Sheets in almost any given level, barring a few exceptions.

Completing Mona's mini-game will give you some gems, potentially making some money back depending on how high your score is. After playing it for the first time, you'll also get the music sheet for her mini-game theme.

I'm going to warn you guys right now: I'm still a bit rusty with most of the bosses in this game. In either case, the Black Knight is easy enough to deal with. He has a predictable set of only a few attacks he'll stick with, which you can easily counter with a down-thrust. He'll also laugh on occasion, which basically gives you a free hit.

You can also get an achievement for putting out your camp-fire after you complete a stage (this will also net you a bit of extra money, so it's a good idea to do this whenever you get the opportunity).

I should note that once you press down while jumping, Shovel Knight will stay in his down-thrust position. This allows you to repeatedly bounce on targets without having to hold any other buttons (as demonstrated here).
Croaker here will tell you a pun-based joke every time you talk with him. I forget how many he has in total, but you'll get an achievement for listening to all of them.

It's been way too long since I've done something a bit different on this channel, but still highly accessible (not just in terms of RPGs). I think it's time to fix that, mainly in the form of "Shovel Knight." This is an indie game brought to us by Yacht Club Games, which derives very strongly from roots in classic platformer games. Despite the whole "8-bit revisiting" formula being done to death in many modern games (even when it's not warranted), this one actually manages to be far more involved - to the point where I'm more than willing to overlook the trait that most would call overused by this point.

Mona's mini-game is self explanatory enough (although I'm not very good at it, in all honesty). Smacking the potions with your shovel will cause them to fly at an upwards arc, which you'll want to position to hit the targets for points. Blue is worth 1, Green is 3, and Red is 10. The glowing potions will split off in five directions when hit, making them ideal for increasing your score.

Time for the basic run-down: Shovel Knight plays like a classic styled platforming game, at least for the most part. There's quite a few things to differentiate all this a bit, mainly in the form of stage design and mechanics built around your movements/attacks. Shovel Knight himself has a short range with his standard attack (understandable, given his choice of weapon), but he also has the ability to dig up treasure from mounds with repeated swings. He also has a down-thrust move somewhat akin to Link's from Zelda II (or Scrooge McDuck's cane, if you prefer), which allows him to bounce off enemies and terrain.

Treasure Chests are rather prevalent in this game as well. They generally come in three different types: Yellow chests tend to hold a varying amount of gems, and almost always give you a pink diamond at the end (some will give you Music Sheets, but these are generally only found in secret or out-of-the-way areas). Red Chests will give you Meal Tickets to increase your health, and are usually only found after you complete a certain number of stages. Blue Chests will give you a unique Relic, albeit in a very specific way (I'll go more into detail on this as they show up).
Of course, once you get your first Ichor from him, you now get to witness the greatest thing anyone will ever see. Ever.

Chester has two Relics at the start: The Chaos Orb fires out a bouncing sphere that damages enemies it passes through. The Fishing Rod meanwhile mostly serves as a way to get a bit of extra gold in some stages (along with a few hidden items in certain levels as well). I was debating on getting the Orb, but at this point, the Fishing Rod is a bit more useful for item gathering.

Now that we have a Relic though, our magic actually serves a purpose. This means we can buy some upgrades from the Magicist - which thankfully only require gold, and not any equivalent to the Meal Tickets. Naturally however, the price for increasing your magic gets higher the further you upgrade it.

The thing that sort of resembles a service bell down there is actually serving tray. Knocking the lid off with your shovel will generally produce different types of food. Carrots and apples will heal a small to moderate amount of health, while turkeys will heal all of your health. Under some circumstances (mostly later in the game), the trays can hold bombs instead of food. In the "New Game Plus" mode, almost every tray has a bomb underneath it.

The "You're Fired" achievement can be obtained by finishing off the Black Knight by deflecting one of his projectiles back at him. Also, I have no idea why Steam didn't display the icon for this achievement either.

Now then, in terms of how I'll be going about with this playthrough: I'm aiming for a 100% completion run here. This means getting every form of unique collectable or upgrade the game has to offer, along with completing every main stage, side/challenge stages, and fighting all the optional bosses as well. I'm also shooting to do all of this without dying, but it's no guarantee (since this is a rather difficult task in its own right, as I'm sure those who have played this game can probably attest).

Once you get done with this however, and if you have the Fishing Rod relic, you can use it on the small space in-between the docks. This will bring up the music sheet for the Troupple King's Waltz song, along with a bunch of apples (as well as enraging the Troupple King himself).
